Note that all folds are made at the same time, so the characters don't have to match in between folds.For example, these are valid foldings of $$$s = \\mathtt{110110110011}$$$ and $$$s = \\mathtt{01110}$$$:The length of the folded strip is the length seen from above after all folds are made. So for the two above examples, after the folds shown above, the lengths would be $$$7$$$ and $$$3$$$, respectively.Notice that for the above folding of $$$s = \\mathtt{01110}$$$, if we made either of the two folds on their own, that would not be a valid folding. processed.result:
You have a strip of paper with a binary string of length $n$. You can fold the paper in between any pair of adjacent digits. A set of folds is valid if after the folds, all characters that are on top of or below each other match.

For example, if the string is  $110110110011$, valid folds could be to fold it in the middle, resulting in a length of 7.

What is the minimum length strip you can form after a valid folding?

Input:

* The first line contains the number of test cases $t$.
* Each test case has two lines:
    * The first line contains the length of the string $n$.
    * The second line contains the binary string.

Output:

* For each test case, output the minimum possible length of the strip after a valid folding.

You have a string of 0s and 1s. You can fold the string at any point between two characters. A fold is valid if all the characters above and below the fold are the same. What is the shortest possible length you can make the string after folding it in a valid way?
